holidays.name: National Teddy Bear Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the beloved stuffed animal, the teddy bear, and its cuddly comfort.
holidays.origin: Created to honor the teddy bear, named after U.S. President Theodore 'Teddy' Roosevelt, inspired by a 1902 hunting trip story.
holidays.funFact: The teddy bear was supposedly invented independently by Morris Michtom in the U.S. and Richard Steiff in Germany around the same time.

holidays.name: International Sudoku Day
holidays.description: A celebration for puzzle lovers to enjoy the logic game Sudoku, sharpening minds worldwide.
holidays.origin: Sudoku became popular globally in the early 2000s, though its roots trace back to 18th-century Swiss mathematician Leonhard Euler's Latin squares.
holidays.funFact: The first Sudoku puzzles were published in Japan in the 1980s, and the name Sudoku means 'single number' in Japanese.

holidays.name: Wonderful Weirdos Day
holidays.description: A day to appreciate and celebrate all the wonderfully weird, extraordinary, quirky people who make life more interesting.
holidays.origin: An unofficial modern observance started on social media to embrace individuality and uniqueness.
holidays.funFact: People celebrate Wonderful Weirdos Day by sharing stories or photos of their quirkiest habits or hobbies.

holidays.name: National Chow Mein Day
holidays.description: A tasty day dedicated to enjoying the crisp and savory flavors of chow mein noodles.
holidays.origin: Chow mein, a Chinese-American dish, became popular in the U.S. in the early 20th century as Chinese immigrants adapted traditional recipes.
holidays.funFact: The term 'chow mein' literally means 'fried noodles' in Cantonese.
